TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and , before his conviction ( described below ) , he lived in ORG , a town in LOC .

CARDINAL . On DATE the police arrested and detained the applicant on suspicion of murder . After the investigation , the police accused him , inter alia , of shooting QUANTITY persons and wounding CARDINAL others , and submitted the case for trial to ORG .

CARDINAL . The trial began on CARDINAL DATE . Before the hearing , the court excluded the public from the court room . Once the hearing had begun , the applicant 's lawyer protested . He argued that the court had acted unlawfully .
CARDINAL . The widow of CARDINAL of the applicant 's purported victims , PERSON , had requested in camera proceedings because she feared “ the defendant 's friends and their threats ” .

CARDINAL . The applicant stated that he saw no reason to hold the hearing in private . The public prosecutor supported PERSON request “ in order to ensure the objectivity of the proceedings ” because , in his opinion , the victims and witnesses were under pressure and feared testifying in public .

CARDINAL . The court deliberated on the spot and decided to continue the hearing in camera in order “ to ensure a comprehensive and objective examination of the case and to avoid any possibility of pressure on the victims and witnesses ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court found the applicant guilty of the premeditated murder of CARDINAL individuals and the attempted murder of another individual in DATE . He was also convicted of the intentional infliction of grievous bodily harm in DATE . The court sentenced the applicant to DATE imprisonment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed to ORG . His lawyer argued , inter alia , that hearing the case in private had been unlawful for a number of reasons . First , under LAW the intimidation of witnesses did not justify hearings in private . Secondly , the court had failed to identify any specific instance of intimidation . Thirdly , only bailiffs could effectively ensure the witnesses ' security .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the appeal after the applicant 's lawyers and a representative of the prosecution had been heard . However , the appeal judgment disregarded the complaint about the trial court hearing in private .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of ORG reduced the applicant 's sentence to DATE imprisonment .

CARDINAL . At the time of the applicant 's trial , criminal proceedings were primarily governed by LAW ( “ the ORG ” ) . LAW ORG established the principle that all hearings should be public . Hearings in private were possible only in cases which involved ORG secrets , sexual offences , cases where the defendant was DATE or where publicity could damage the participants ' private life .

CARDINAL . Apart from the ORG , criminal proceedings were governed by LAW GPE of DATE , which remained in force at the time of the applicant 's trial . Under LAW of LAW , hearings in private were also possible to ensure the security of the victims and witnesses .
